Safari.Name: Debug CSS animations
Safari.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Open the "Timelines" tab > Ensure that "Media and Animations" is enabled in the left panel.
2. Now reload the page or trigger the animation to see the timeline in the bottom panel.

Opera.Notes:
1. Run **Command Menu** > Search for "Show Animations" and press `Enter`.
2. (Or) Click on the "Customise and control Devtools" button in the top right > More Tools > Animations.
Opera.Name: Debug CSS animation

Firefox.Notes: 1. Inspect the element which uses CSS animation. Click on the "Animations" tab next to the DOM tree in the side panel.
Firefox.Name: Debug CSS animations

Edge.Notes:
1. Launch Devtools > Open "Command Menu" by using Cmd+Shit+P (on Mac) or Ctrl+Shift+P (on Windows/Linux/Chrome OS).
2. Search for "Show Animations" and press Enter (this will open the "Animations" drawer next to the Console).
Edge.Name: Debug CSS animation

Chrome.Notes:
1. Run **Command Menu** > Search for "Show Animations" and press `Enter`.
2. (Or) Click on the "Customise and control Devtools" button in the top right > More Tools > Animations.
Chrome.Name: Debug CSS animation

Safari.Name: Debug attr change
Safari.Notes:
1. Inspect element > Right click on the DOM node > Select "Break on" > Select "Attribute Modified".
2. Reload the page.

Opera.Notes:
1. Inspect element > Right click on the node in the DOM tree.
2. Select "Break on" > "attribute modifications". Reload the page.
Opera.Name: Debug attr change

Firefox.Notes:
1. Inspect element > Right click on the node in the DOM tree.
2. Select "Break on..." > "Attribute Modification". Reload the page.
Firefox.Name: Debug attr change

Edge.Notes:
1. Inspect element > Right click on the node in the DOM tree > Select "Break on" > Select "attribute modifications". 
2. Reload the page.
Edge.Name: Debug attr change

Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect element > Right click on the node in the DOM tree.
2. Select "Break on" > "attribute modifications". Reload the page.
Chrome.Name: Debug attr change

Safari.Name: Clear console
Safari.Notes:
Three ways to clear a console:
1. Press `Cmd+K` or `Ctrl+L` on the keyboard.
2. Click the Trash icon in the top-right of the console toolbar.
3. Use `console.clear()` on the command line.

Opera.Notes:
Three ways to clear a console:
1. Press `Ctrl+L` (on Windows/Linux) or `Cmd+K` (on MacOS) to clear the console.
2. Click on the "Clear Console" icon in the toolbar on the top left side.
3. Use `console.clear()` on the command line.
Opera.Name: Clear console

Firefox.Notes:
Three ways to clear a console:
1. Press `Ctrl+L` (on Windows/Linux) or `Cmd+K` (on MacOS) to clear the console.
2. Click on the "Clear the Web Console output" icon in the toolbar on the top left side.
3. Use `console.clear()` on the command line.
Firefox.Name: Clear console

Edge.Notes:
Three ways to clear a console:
1. Press `Ctrl+L` (on Windows/Linux) or `Cmd+K` (on MacOS) to clear the console.
2. Click on the "Clear Console" icon in the toolbar on the top left side.
3. Use `console.clear()` on the command line.
Edge.Name: Clear console

Chrome.Notes:
Three ways to clear a console:
1. Press `Ctrl+L` (on Windows/Linux) or `Cmd+K` (on MacOS) to clear the console.
2. Click on the "Clear Console" icon in the toolbar on the top left side.
3. Use `console.clear()` on the command line.
Chrome.Name: Clear console

Safari.Name: Open devtools with a keyboard
Safari.Notes:
In the menu bar, navigate to Safari > Preferences > Click on the **Advanced** tab, check "Show Develop menu in menu bar".

Press `Option+Cmd+I` to open the devtools.

Opera.Notes: 1. Launch Chrome > Press `F12`. Alternatively, you can also use `Cmd+Option+I` (on Mac) and `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux) to open the last used panel.
Opera.Name: Open devtools with Keyboard

Firefox.Notes: 1. Launch Firefox → Press `F12`.
Firefox.Name: Open devtools with a keyboard

Edge.Notes: 1. Launch Edge → Press `F12`.
Edge.Name: Open devtools with a keyboard

Chrome.Notes: 1. Launch Chrome > Press `F12`. Alternatively, you can also use `Cmd+Option+I` (on Mac) and `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux) to open the last used panel.
Chrome.Name: Open devtools with Keyboard

Safari.Name: Debug JavaScript
Safari.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Click on the Sources tab. In the File Navigator pane on the bottom left, locate the source file. 
2. Select the file (this will open the code in the Code Editor pane).
3. You'll find all the debugging tools in the JavaScript debug pane in the top left of the tab.

Opera.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Click on the Sources tab. In the File Navigator pane on the left (under Page), locate the source file. 
2. Select the file (this will open the code in the Code Editor pane).
3. On the right of the Code Editor pane, you'll find all the debugging tools in the JavaScript debug pane.
Opera.Name: Debug JavaScript

Firefox.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Click on the Debugger tab. In the File Navigator pane on the left (under Sources), locate the source file. 
2. Select the file (this will open the code in the Code Editor pane).
3. On the right of the Code Editor pane, you'll find all the debugging tools in the JavaScript debug pane.
Firefox.Name: Debug JavaScript

Edge.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Click on the Sources tab. In the File Navigator pane on the left (under Page), locate the source file. 
2. Select the file (this will open the code in the Code Editor pane).
3. On the right of the Code Editor pane, you'll find all the debugging tools in the JavaScript debug pane.
Edge.Name: Debug JavaScript

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Click on the Sources tab. In the File Navigator pane on the left (under Page), locate the source file. 
2. Select the file (this will open the code in the Code Editor pane).
3. On the right of the Code Editor pane, you'll find all the debugging tools in the JavaScript debug pane.
Chrome.Name: Debug JavaScript

Safari.Name: Output data as table
Safari.Notes: Open **Console** using `Cmd+Opt+C`. Use `console.table()` to output arrays of array or array of objects in a sortable, tabular format.

Opera.Notes:
1. Open console using `Cmd+Opt+J` or `Ctrl+Shift+J`.
2. Use `console.table()` to output an array of arrays, or array of objects in a sortable, tabular format. For example, 
```
console.table([[10, true, "blue"],[5, false]])
```
1. If the number of elements in each object is not equal, the table will display `undefined` in cells for which there is no data.
2. There is an optional second argument which allows you to explicitly specify which columns to output.
```
console.table([
  {population:8173194, country:"UK", elevation:"24m"},
  {population:8336697, country:"USA", elevation:"10m"}
],["population", "country"])
```
Opera.Name: Output data as table

Firefox.Notes:
Open **Console** using `Cmd+Opt+K` or `Ctrl+Shift+K` > Use `console.table()` to output the object in tabulated format.

Example:
```
console.table([
  {population:8173194, country:"UK", elevation:"24m"},
  {population:8336697, country:"USA", elevation:"10m"}
],["population", "country"])
```
Firefox.Name: Output data as table

Edge.Notes:
1. Open console using `Cmd+Opt+J` or `Ctrl+Shift+J`.
2. Use `console.table()` to output an array of arrays, or array of objects in a sortable, tabular format. For example, 
```
console.table([[10, true, "blue"],[5, false]])
```
1. If the number of elements in each object is not equal, the table will display `undefined` in cells for which there is no data.
2. There is an optional second argument which allows you to explicitly specify which columns to output.
```
console.table([
  {population:8173194, country:"UK", elevation:"24m"},
  {population:8336697, country:"USA", elevation:"10m"}
],["population", "country"])
```
Edge.Name: Output data as table

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open console using `Cmd+Opt+J` or `Ctrl+Shift+J`.
2. Use `console.table()` to output an array of arrays, or array of objects in a sortable, tabular format. For example, 
```
console.table([[10, true, "blue"],[5, false]])
```
1. If the number of elements in each object is not equal, the table will display `undefined` in cells for which there is no data.
2. There is an optional second argument which allows you to explicitly specify which columns to output.
```
console.table([
  {population:8173194, country:"UK", elevation:"24m"},
  {population:8336697, country:"USA", elevation:"10m"}
],["population", "country"])
```
Chrome.Name: Output data as table

Safari.Name: Disable cache
Safari.Notes: 1. Open Network panel > Look for the icon in the top right of the toolbar with tooltip "Ignore the resource cache when loading resources".

Opera.Notes: 1. Open Network panel > Look for "Disable cache" in the toolbar at the top.
Opera.Name: Disable cache

Firefox.Notes: 1. Open Network panel > Look for "Disable Cache" in the toolbar at the top.
Firefox.Name: Disable cache

Edge.Notes: 1. Open Network panel > Look for "Disable Cache" in the toolbar at the top.
Edge.Name: Disable cache

Chrome.Notes: 1. Open Network panel > Look for "Disable cache" in the toolbar at the top.
Chrome.Name: Disable cache

Safari.Name: Filter requests
Safari.Notes: 1. In the **Network** tab, use the "Filter Full URL" input field to filter network requests for a specific keyword.

Opera.Notes:
1. Open the **Network** tab > Use the "Filter" input field to filter network requests based on a specific keyword. 
2. Use the "Invert" checkbox to filter on requests which does not match the keyword.
Opera.Name: Filter requests

Firefox.Notes:
1. In the **Network** tab, use the "Filter URLs" text field to filter the network requests for a specific keyword. 
2. Prepending a minus (`-`) negates the filter. You can combine different filters together by separating them with a space.
Firefox.Name: Filter requests

Edge.Notes:
1. Open the **Network** tab > Use the "Filter" input field to filter network requests based on a specific keyword. 
2. Use the "Invert" checkbox to filter on requests which does not match the keyword.
Edge.Name: Filter requests

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open the **Network** tab > Use the "Filter" input field to filter network requests based on a specific keyword. 
2. Use the "Invert" checkbox to filter on requests which does not match the keyword.
Chrome.Name: Filter requests

Firefox.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Debugger > Find and expand the Event Listener Breakpoints section in the right hand column.
2. To break when event listeners are hit, check the boxes next the events you are interested in. All of the standard events supported in your version of Firefox are listed, arranged by which API or API area they’re part of.
Firefox.References:
1. "Set event listener breakpoints" by [Firefox](https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/devtools-user/debugger/set_event_listener_breakpoints/index.html).
2. "Examine Event Listeners" by [Firefox](https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/devtools-user/page_inspector/how_to/examine_event_listeners/index.html#examine-event-listeners).
3. "Issue #5" by [@nclm](https://github.com/pankajparashar/canidev.tools/issues/5).
Firefox.Name: Debug Event Listeners

Safari.Name: Emulate color schemes
Safari.Notes: Open **Web Inspector** using `Cmd+Opt+I`. Look for the icon in the top right of the Elements panel, to toggle between "Force Dark Appearance" and "Use Default Appearance".

Opera.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Inside the "Styles" pane, right next to the "+" button, click the Icon "Toggle common rendering emulations".
2. Choose the `prefers-color-scheme` option to emulate the corresponding color scheme.
Opera.Name: Emulate color schemes

Firefox.Notes: 1. Open devtools > Inspector > Next to the "Filter Styles" section, are the icons to toggle between light, dark color schemes.
Firefox.Name: Emulate color schemes

Edge.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Inside the "Styles" pane, right next to the "+" button, click the Icon "Toggle common rendering emulations".
2. Choose the `prefers-color-scheme` option to emulate the corresponding color scheme.
Edge.Name: Emulate color schemes

Chrome.References:
1. via [@jecfish](https://twitter.com/jecfish/status/1514209534566313986) on Twitter
2. via [@Una](https://twitter.com/Una/status/1514624082909831168) on Twitter
Chrome.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Inside the "Styles" pane, right next to the "+" button, click the Icon "Toggle common rendering emulations".
2. Choose the `prefers-color-scheme` option to emulate the corresponding color scheme.
Chrome.Name: Emulate color schemes

Opera.Notes:
1. Click the **Sources** tab.
2. Expand the **XHR Breakpoints** pane.
3. Click **Add breakpoint**.
4. Enter the string which you want to break on. DevTools pauses when this string is present anywhere in an XHR's request URL.
5. Press Enter to confirm.
Opera.Name: Debug XHR/Fetch calls

Firefox.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Debugger. 
2. In the right section, under "XHR Breakpoints",  either use the checkbox to "Pause on any URL" or "Break when the URL contains" a specific keyword
Firefox.Name: Debug XHR/Fetch calls

Edge.Notes:
1. Click the Sources tab.
2. Expand the XHR Breakpoints pane.
3. Click Add breakpoint.
4. Enter the string which you want to break on. DevTools pauses when this string is present anywhere in an XHR's request URL.
5. Press Enter to confirm.
Edge.Name: Debug XHR/Fetch calls

Chrome.Notes:
1. Click the **Sources** tab.
2. Expand the **XHR Breakpoints** pane.
3. Click **Add breakpoint**.
4. Enter the string which you want to break on. DevTools pauses when this string is present anywhere in an XHR's request URL.
5. Press Enter to confirm.
Chrome.Name: Debug XHR/Fetch calls

Safari.Name: View styles of element
Safari.Notes:
1. Right click on the element and select "Inspect Element" (This will open the "Elements" panel in the devtools with selected element highlighted in the DOM tree).
2. The CSS applied to the element is visible in the panel, adjacent to the DOM tree.

Opera.Notes:
1. Right click on the element and select "Inspect" (This will open the Elements panel in the devtools with selected element highlighted in the DOM tree).  
2. The CSS applied to the element is visible in the "Styles" tab, adjacent to the DOM tree.
Opera.Name: View styles of element

Firefox.Notes:
1. Right click on the element and select "Inspect" (This will open the "Inspector" panel in the devtools with selected element highlighted in the DOM tree).
2. The CSS applied to the element is visible in the panel, adjacent to the DOM tree.
Firefox.Name: View styles of element

Edge.Notes:
1. Right click on the element and select "Inspect". (This will open the Elements panel in the devtools with selected element highlighted in the DOM tree).
2. The CSS applied to the element is visible in the "Styles" tab, adjacent to the DOM tree.
Edge.Name: View styles of element

Chrome.Notes:
1. Right click on the element and select "Inspect" (This will open the Elements panel in the devtools with selected element highlighted in the DOM tree).  
2. The CSS applied to the element is visible in the "Styles" tab, adjacent to the DOM tree.
Chrome.Name: View styles of element

Safari.Name: Inspect requests
Safari.Notes: 1. Open devtools > Click on the Network panel (This will show a section containing table of network requests).

Opera.Notes: 1. Open devtools > Click on the Network panel (This will show a section containing table of network requests).
Opera.Name: Inspect requests

Firefox.Notes: 1. Open devtools > Click on the Network panel (This will show a section containing table of network requests).
Firefox.Name: Inspect requests

Edge.Notes: 1. Open devtools > Click on the Network panel (This will show a section containing table of network requests).
Edge.Name: Inspect requests

Chrome.Notes: 1. Open devtools > Click on the Network panel (This will show a section containing table of network requests).
Chrome.Name: Inspect requests

Safari.Name: Find by XPath
Safari.Notes:
1. Open devtools using Cmd+Opt+I (on MacOS) or Ctrl+Shift+I (on Windows/Linux/ChromeOS) > Elements.
2. Press Cmd+F or Ctrl+F to open the search bar at the top of the Elements panel.
3. Enter the xpath to find the element in the DOM node.

Opera.Notes:
1. Open devtools using Cmd+Opt+I (on MacOS) or Ctrl+Shift+I (on Windows/Linux/ChromeOS) > Elements.
2. Press Cmd+F or Ctrl+F to open the search bar at the bottom of the Elements panel.
3. Enter XPath to find the element in the DOM node.
Opera.Name: Find by XPath

Firefox.Notes:
1. Open devtools using Cmd+Opt+I (on MacOS) or Ctrl+Shift+I (on Windows/Linux/ChromeOS) > Inspector.
2. Press Cmd+F or Ctrl+F to open the search bar at the top of the Inspector panel.
3. Enter the xpath to find the element in the DOM node.
Firefox.Name: Find by XPath

Edge.Notes:
1. Open devtools using Cmd+Opt+I (on MacOS) or Ctrl+Shift+I (on Windows/Linux/ChromeOS) > Elements.
2. Press Cmd+F or Ctrl+F to open the search bar at the bottom of the Elements panel.
3. Enter XPath to find the element in the DOM node.
Edge.Name: Find by XPath

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open devtools using Cmd+Opt+I (on MacOS) or Ctrl+Shift+I (on Windows/Linux/ChromeOS) > Elements.
2. Press Cmd+F or Ctrl+F to open the search bar at the bottom of the Elements panel.
3. Enter XPath to find the element in the DOM node.
Chrome.Name: Find by XPath

Safari.Name: Filter multiple resources
Safari.Notes: Open devtools > Open the Network tab. Hold `Cmd` or `Ctrl` key while clicking on the Resource type.

Opera.Notes: Open devtools > Open the "Network" tab. Hold `Cmd` or `Ctrl` key while clicking on the Resource type.
Opera.Name: Filter multiple resources

Firefox.Notes: Open devtools > Open the Network tab. Hold `Cmd` or `Ctrl` key while clicking on the Resource type.
Firefox.Name: Filter multiple resources

Edge.Notes: Open devtools > Open the Network tab. Hold `Cmd` or `Ctrl` key while clicking on the Resource type.
Edge.Name: Filter multiple resources

Chrome.References:
1. "Filter request by Type" by [Chrome Developers](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/devtools/network/reference/#filter-by-type) 
2. "Tips & Tricks #1" of the [Newsletter](https://www.getrevue.co/profile/CanIDevTools/issues/tips-tricks-1-1155265)
Chrome.Notes: Open devtools > Open the "Network" tab. Hold `Cmd` or `Ctrl` key while clicking on the Resource type.
Chrome.Name: Filter multiple resources

Safari.Name: Add a CSS declaration to an element
Safari.Notes:
1. Right click on the element and select "Inspect Element" (This will open the Elements panel in the devtools with selected element highlighted in the DOM tree). 
2. Click inside the curly braces of the "Style Attribute" section in the adjacent panel (next to the DOM tree). Enter the declaration you want in the "property: value" format.

Opera.Notes:
1. Right click on the element and select "Inspect" (This will open the Elements panel in the devtools with selected element highlighted in the DOM tree). 
2. Click "element.style" near the top of the Styles tab. Enter the declaration you want in the "property: value" format.
Opera.Name: Add a CSS declaration to an element

Firefox.Notes:
1. Right click on the element and select "Inspect" (This will open the Inspector panel in the devtools with selected element highlighted in the DOM tree). 
2. Click "element" in the adjacent styles panel. Enter the declaration you want in the "property: value" format.
Firefox.Name: Add a CSS declaration to an element

Edge.Notes:
1. Right click on the element and select "Inspect" (This will open the Elements panel in the devtools with selected element highlighted in the DOM tree). 
2. Click "element.style" near the top of the Styles tab. Enter the declaration you want in the "property: value" format.
Edge.Name: Add a CSS declaration to an element

Chrome.Notes:
1. Right click on the element and select "Inspect" (This will open the Elements panel in the devtools with selected element highlighted in the DOM tree). 
2. Click "element.style" near the top of the Styles tab. Enter the declaration you want in the "property: value" format.
Chrome.Name: Add a CSS declaration to an element

Opera.Notes:
1. In the _Styles_ pane, hold the `Shift` key and click on any color preview to change the color format. The HWB color format is added.
2. Alternatively, you can change the color format to HWB in the [color picker](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/devtools/css/reference/#color-picker).
Opera.Name: HWB color format

Firefox.Notes:
1. In the Styles pane, hold the `Shift` key and click on any color preview to change the color format. The HWB color format is added.
2. It is also available as an [optional default](https://firefox-source-docs.mozilla.org/devtools-user/settings/index.html#inspector).
Firefox.Name: HWB color format

Edge.Notes:
1. In the _Styles_ pane, hold the `Shift` key and click on any color preview to change the color format. The HWB color format is added.
2. Alternatively, you can change the color format to HWB in the [color picker](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/devtools/css/reference/#color-picker).
Edge.Name: HWB color format

Chrome.References: 1. "Support for the hwb() color function" on [Chrome Developers](https://developer.chrome.com/blog/new-in-devtools-101/#hwb) by Jecelyn Yeen
Chrome.Notes:
1. In the _Styles_ pane, hold the `Shift` key and click on any color preview to change the color format. The HWB color format is added.
2. Alternatively, you can change the color format to HWB in the [color picker](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/devtools/css/reference/#color-picker).
Chrome.Name: HWB color format

Safari.Name: Style console logs
Safari.Notes:
1. Open console (`Cmd+Option+J` or `Ctrl+Shift+J`).
2. Prefix the log statement with `%c`, and supply the CSS styles as the second argument to `console.log()`

For example, 
```
console.log(
  "%cThis is green text with yellow background",
  "color:green; background:yellow"
)
```

Opera.Notes:
1. Open console using `Cmd+Option+J` or `Ctrl+Shift+J`.
2. Prefix the log statement with `%c`, and supply the CSS styles as the second argument to `console.log()`. For example, 
```
console.log(
  "%cThis is green text with yellow background",
  "color:green; background:yellow"
)
```
Opera.Name: Style console logs

Firefox.Notes:
1. Open console using `Cmd+Option+J` or `Ctrl+Shift+J`.
2. Prefix the log statement with `%c`, and supply the CSS styles as the second argument to `console.log()`

For example, 
```
console.log(
  "%cThis is green text with yellow background",
  "color:green; background:yellow"
)
```
Firefox.Name: Style console logs

Edge.Notes:
1. Open console (`Cmd+Option+J` or `Ctrl+Shift+J`).
2. Prefix the log statement with `%c`, and supply the CSS styles as the second argument to `console.log()`

For example, 
```
console.log(
  "%cThis is green text with yellow background",
  "color:green; background:yellow"
)
```
Edge.Name: Style console logs

Chrome.References:
1. "Secrets of the Browser Developer Tools" by [devtoolsecrets.com](http://devtoolsecrets.com/)
2. Tips & Tricks #2 of the [Newsletter](https://www.getrevue.co/profile/CanIDevTools/issues/tips-tricks-2-1159708)
Chrome.Notes:
1. Open console using `Cmd+Option+J` or `Ctrl+Shift+J`.
2. Prefix the log statement with `%c`, and supply the CSS styles as the second argument to `console.log()`. For example, 
```
console.log(
  "%cThis is green text with yellow background",
  "color:green; background:yellow"
)
```
Chrome.Name: Style console logs

Safari.Name: Capture node screenshot
Safari.Notes: 1. Inspect element > Right click on the node in the DOM tree and click on "Capture Screenshot"

Opera.Notes: 1. Inspect element > Right click on the node in the DOM tree and select "Capture node screenshot".
Opera.Name: Capture node screenshot

Firefox.Notes: 1. Inspect the element > Right click on the node in the DOM tree, and select "Screenshot node"
Firefox.Name: Capture node screenshot

Edge.Notes: 1. Inspect element > Right click on the node in the DOM tree and click "Capture node screenshot"
Edge.Name: Capture node screenshot

Chrome.Notes: 1. Inspect element > Right click on the node in the DOM tree and select "Capture node screenshot".
Chrome.Name: Capture node screenshot

Opera.Notes:
1. Launch Devtools > Open Command Menu using "Cmd+Shift+P" (on Mac) or "Ctrl+Shift+P" (on Windows/Linus/Chrome OS).
2. Search for "Show Coverage" (this will open the Coverage drawer next to the Console).
3. Click the "Reload" button to see the unused styles per CSS file.
Opera.Name: Find unused CSS

Edge.Notes:
1. Launch Devtools > Open Command Menu using "Cmd+Shift+P" (on Mac) or "Ctrl+Shift+P" (on Windows/Linus/Chrome OS).
2. Search for "Show Coverage" (this will open the Coverage drawer next to the Console).
3. Click the "Reload" button to see the unused styles per CSS file.
Edge.Name: Find unused CSS

Chrome.Notes:
1. Launch Devtools > Open Command Menu using "Cmd+Shift+P" (on Mac) or "Ctrl+Shift+P" (on Windows/Linus/Chrome OS).
2. Search for "Show Coverage" (this will open the Coverage drawer next to the Console).
3. Click the "Reload" button to see the unused styles per CSS file.
Chrome.Name: Find unused CSS

Opera.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Launch Command menu > Search for "Capture screenshot".
2. Press Enter to capture the screenshot of the viewport.
Opera.Name: Capture viewport screenshot

Firefox.Notes: 1. Right click on the page > Click "Take screenshot"
Firefox.Name: Capture viewport screenshot

Edge.Notes: 1. Open devtools > Open command menu > Search for "Capture  screenshot"
Edge.Name: Capture viewport screenshot

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Launch Command menu > Search for "Capture screenshot".
2. Press Enter to capture the screenshot of the viewport.
Chrome.Name: Capture viewport screenshot

Opera.Notes:
1. Launch Devtools > Open Command Menu using "Cmd+Shift+P" (on Mac) or "Ctrl+Shift+P" (on Windows/Linus/Chrome OS).
2. Search for "Show Coverage" (this will open the Coverage drawer next to the Console).
3. Click the "Reload" button to see the unused JavaScript per file.
Opera.Name: Find unused JavaScript

Edge.Notes:
1. Launch Devtools > Open Command Menu using "Cmd+Shift+P" (on Mac) or "Ctrl+Shift+P" (on Windows/Linus/Chrome OS).
2. Search for "Show Coverage" (this will open the Coverage drawer next to the Console).
3. Click the "Reload" button to see the unused JavaScript per file.
Edge.Name: Find unused JavaScript

Chrome.Notes:
1. Launch Devtools > Open Command Menu using "Cmd+Shift+P" (on Mac) or "Ctrl+Shift+P" (on Windows/Linus/Chrome OS).
2. Search for "Show Coverage" (this will open the Coverage drawer next to the Console).
3. Click the "Reload" button to see the unused JavaScript per file.
Chrome.Name: Find unused JavaScript

Safari.Name: Open devtools with a mouse
Safari.Notes:
1. Launch Safari → In the menu bar, navigate to Safari > Preferences → Click on the General tab, check "Show Developer menu in menu bar".
2. Again in the menu bar, navigate to Develop > Show Web Inspector.

Opera.Notes:
1. Launch Chrome → Click on the vertical three dots icon (near top right of the window).
2. Navigate to More Tools > Developer Tools.
Opera.Name: Open devtools with a mouse

Firefox.Notes:
1. Launch Firefox → Click on the hamburger icon (near top right of the window).
2. Navigate to "More Tools" > "Web Developer Tools".
Firefox.Name: Open devtools with a mouse

Edge.Notes:
1. Launch Edge → Click on the horizontal three dots icon (near top right of the window).
2. Navigate to More Tools > Developer Tools.
Edge.Name: Open devtools with a mouse

Chrome.Notes:
1. Launch Chrome → Click on the vertical three dots icon (near top right of the window).
2. Navigate to More Tools > Developer Tools.
Chrome.Name: Open devtools with a mouse

Safari.Name: Run previous commands
Safari.Notes: 1. Use the `Up` arrow key to scroll through the list of previously executed commands and then press `Enter`.

Opera.Notes: 1. Use the `Up` arrow key to scroll through the list of previously executed commands and then press `Enter`.
Opera.Name: Run previous commands

Firefox.Notes: 1. Use the `Up` arrow key to scroll through the list of previously executed commands and then press `Enter`.
Firefox.Name: Run previous commands

Edge.Notes: 1. Use the `Up` arrow key to scroll through the list of previously executed commands and then press `Enter`.
Edge.Name: Run previous commands

Chrome.Notes: 1. Use the `Up` arrow key to scroll through the list of previously executed commands and then press `Enter`.
Chrome.Name: Run previous commands

Opera.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Click the "Elements" panel > Press `Cmd+F` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+F` (on Windows/Linux/Chrome OS) to open the search bar.
2. Enter the CSS selector to search an element in the DOM tree.
Opera.Name: Find element using CSS selector

Firefox.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Click the "Inspector" tab to open the DOM tree > Under the Inspector tab, locate the "Search HTML" field.
2. Enter the CSS selector to search the element in the DOM tree.
Firefox.Name: Find element using CSS selector

Edge.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Click the "Elements" panel > Press `Cmd+F` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+F` (on Windows/Linux/Chrome OS) to open the search bar.
2. Enter the CSS selector to search an element in the DOM tree.
Edge.Name: Find element using CSS selector

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Click the "Elements" panel > Press `Cmd+F` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+F` (on Windows/Linux/Chrome OS) to open the search bar.
2. Enter the CSS selector to search an element in the DOM tree.
Chrome.Name: Find element using CSS selector

Safari.Name: Add class to element
Safari.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Look for "Classes" button in bottom row of the styles section next to the Filter field.
2. Click the button and search for the existing class names to add to the element.

Opera.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Look for ".cls" button in the Styles pane next to the Filter field.
2. Click the button and search for the existing class names to add to the element.
Opera.Name: Add class to element

Firefox.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Look for ".cls" button in the styles section next to the Filter Styles field.
2. Click the button and search for the existing class names to add to the element.
Firefox.Name: Add class to element

Edge.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Look for ".cls" button in the Styles pane next to the Filter field.
2. Click the button and search for the existing class names to add to the element.
Edge.Name: Add class to element

Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Look for ".cls" button in the Styles pane next to the Filter field.
2. Click the button and search for the existing class names to add to the element.
Chrome.Name: Add class to element

Safari.Name: Get selected node
Safari.Notes:
1. Inspect > Select a DOM node.
2. Open Console > Use $0 to access the currently selected node.

Opera.Notes:
1. Inspect > Select a DOM node.
2. Open Console > Use $0 to access the currently selected node. Additionally, $1, $2, $3, ... will give you the last selected nodes in the reverse chronological order.
Opera.Name: Get selected node

Firefox.Notes:
1. Inspect > Select a DOM node.
2. Open Console > Use $0 to access the currently selected node.
Firefox.Name: Get selected node

Edge.Notes:
1. Inspect > Select a DOM node.
2. Open Console > Use $0 to access the currently selected node. Additionally, $1, $2, $3, ... will give you the last selected nodes in the reverse chronological order.
Edge.Name: Get selected node

Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect > Select a DOM node.
2. Open Console > Use $0 to access the currently selected node. Additionally, $1, $2, $3, ... will give you the last selected nodes in the reverse chronological order.
Chrome.Name: Get selected node

Opera.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux) > Memory.
2. Check memory usage > Memory going only ⬆️ is a bad sign! > Capture snapshot to preview memory allocation > Find redundant objects > Navigate to where you allocated them.
Opera.Name: Detect memory leaks

Edge.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux) > Memory.
2. Check memory usage > Memory going only ⬆️ is a bad sign! > Capture snapshot to preview memory allocation > Find redundant objects > Navigate to where you allocated them.
Edge.Name: Detect memory leaks

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux) > Memory.
2. Check memory usage > Memory going only ⬆️ is a bad sign! > Capture snapshot to preview memory allocation > Find redundant objects > Navigate to where you allocated them.
Chrome.Name: Detect memory leaks

Safari.Name: View computed CSS properties
Safari.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Navigate to the Computed tab in the panel next to the DOM tree.
2. Click the filter icon > Select "Show All" to see all the inherited values.

Opera.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Navigate to the Computed tab in the panel next to the DOM tree.
2. Click the "Show All" checkbox to see all the inherited values.
Opera.Name: View computed CSS properties

Firefox.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Navigate to the Computed tab in the panel next to the DOM tree.
2. Click the "Browser Styles" checkbox to see all the values inherited from the user agent.
Firefox.Name: View computed CSS properties

Edge.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Navigate to the Computed tab in the panel next to the DOM tree.
2. Click the "Show All" checkbox to see all the inherited values.
Edge.Name: View computed CSS properties

Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Navigate to the Computed tab in the panel next to the DOM tree.
2. Click the "Show All" checkbox to see all the inherited values.
Chrome.Name: View computed CSS properties

Safari.Name: Emulate print styles
Safari.Notes: 1. Launch devtools > Select the body `DOM` element, and click on the "Printer" icon to force the page to use print media styles

Opera.Notes:
1. Launch devtools > Open "Command Menu" using `Cmd+Shift+P` (Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+P` (Windows, Linux, Chrome OS).
2. Search for "Show Rendering" and press Enter (this will open the Rendering panel next to the Console).
3. Scroll down to the section "Emulate CSS Media Type" and select "print".
Opera.Name: Emulate print styles

Firefox.Notes: 1. Inspect > In the "Filter Styles" section on the right, look for the icon with the title, "Toggle print media simulation for the page".
Firefox.Name: Emulate print styles

Edge.Notes:
1. Launch devtools > Open "Command Menu" using `Cmd+Shift+P` (Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+P` (Windows, Linux, Chrome OS).
2. Search for "Show Rendering" and press Enter (this will open the Rendering panel next to the Console).
3. Scroll down to the section "Emulate CSS Media Type" and select "print".
Edge.Name: Emulate print styles

Chrome.Notes:
1. Launch devtools > Open "Command Menu" using `Cmd+Shift+P` (Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+P` (Windows, Linux, Chrome OS).
2. Search for "Show Rendering" and press Enter (this will open the Rendering panel next to the Console).
3. Scroll down to the section "Emulate CSS Media Type" and select "print".
Chrome.Name: Emulate print styles

Safari.Name: View styles for pseudo classes
Safari.Notes:
1. Inspect an element > Make sure the node is selected in the DOM Tree.
2. In the styles section (next to the DOM tree), right at the top toolbar, you'll find checkboxes for different pseudo states, which you can toggle to view the corresponding CSS.

Opera.Notes:
1. Inspect an element > Make sure the node is selected in the DOM Tree.
2. In the Styles pane (next to the DOM tree), look for ":hov" button next to the Filter box > Click the ":hov" button.
3. Use the checkboxes to force the element state to any of the listed pseudo classes to view the corresponding CSS applied.
Opera.Name: View styles for pseudo classes

Firefox.Notes:
1. Inspect an element > Make sure the node is selected in the DOM Tree.
2. In the styles section (next to the DOM tree), look for ":hov" button next to the Filter box > Click the ":hov" button.
3. Use the checkboxes to force the element state to any of the listed pseudo classes to view the corresponding CSS applied.
Firefox.Name: View styles for pseudo classes

Edge.Notes:
1. Inspect an element > Make sure the node is selected in the DOM Tree.
2. In the Styles pane (next to the DOM tree), look for ":hov" button next to the Filter box > Click the ":hov" button.
3. Use the checkboxes to force the element state to any of the listed pseudo classes to view the corresponding CSS applied.
Edge.Name: View styles for pseudo classes

Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect an element > Make sure the node is selected in the DOM Tree.
2. In the Styles pane (next to the DOM tree), look for ":hov" button next to the Filter box > Click the ":hov" button.
3. Use the checkboxes to force the element state to any of the listed pseudo classes to view the corresponding CSS applied.
Chrome.Name: View styles for pseudo classes

Safari.Name: View cascade layers
Safari.Notes: 1. Inspect the element that is part of the `@layer`. In the Styles pane, each layer and its corresponding styles are visible.

Opera.Notes:
1. Inspect the element that is part of the `@layer`. In the **Styles** pane, each layer and its corresponding styles are visible.
2. Clicking on the layer name will reveal the **CSS layers** section at the top which will contain the layer order, that drives the specificity.
Opera.Name: View cascade layers

Firefox.Notes: 1. Inspect the element that is part of the `@layer`. In the Styles pane, each layer and its corresponding styles are visible.
Firefox.Name: View cascade layers

Edge.Notes:
1. Inspect the element that is part of the `@layer`. In the **Styles** pane, each layer and its corresponding styles are visible.
2. Clicking on the layer name will reveal the **CSS layers** section at the top which will contain the layer order, that drives the specificity.
Edge.Name: View cascade layers

Chrome.References:
1. "What's New In DevTools (Chrome 101)" - [Chrome Developers](https://developer.chrome.com/blog/new-in-devtools-101/#layer)
2. "CSS Cascade Layer Demo" - [Jecelyn Yeen](https://jec.fyi/demo/cascade-layer)
Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect the element that is part of the `@layer`. In the **Styles** pane, each layer and its corresponding styles are visible.
2. Clicking on the layer name will reveal the **CSS layers** section at the top which will contain the layer order, that drives the specificity.
Chrome.Name: View cascade layers

Safari.Name: Disable JavaScript
Safari.Notes:
1. In the menu bar, navigate to Safari > Preferences.
2. Click on the Security tab. Under the Web Content section, uncheck the "Enable JavaScript" checkbox.

Opera.Notes:
1. Open devtools. Press `Shift+Cmd+P` on Mac or `Ctrl+Shit+P` on Windows/Linux/Chrome OS to open the Command Menu.
2. Search for "Disable JavaScript" and press `Enter` to execute the command.
3. The yellow warning icon next to the Sources panel is the indicator that the JavaScript is disabled. It will continue to be disabled until the devtools is closed.
Opera.Name: Disable JavaScript

Firefox.Notes:
1. Navigate to `about:config` in the address bar. Click on "Accept the Risk and Continue" while proceeding with caution.
2. Search for "javascript.enabled" in the preference textbox.
3. Toggle the boolean value to False, using the `⇋` button.
Firefox.Name: Disable JavaScript

Edge.Notes:
1. Open devtools. Press `Shift+Cmd+P` on Mac or `Ctrl+Shit+P` on Windows/Linux/Chrome OS to open the Command Menu.
2. Search for "Disable JavaScript" and press `Enter` to execute the command.
3. The yellow warning icon next to the Sources panel is the indicator that the JavaScript is disabled. It will continue to be disabled until the devtools is closed.
Edge.Name: Disable JavaScript

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open devtools. Press `Shift+Cmd+P` on Mac or `Ctrl+Shit+P` on Windows/Linux/Chrome OS to open the Command Menu.
2. Search for "Disable JavaScript" and press `Enter` to execute the command.
3. The yellow warning icon next to the Sources panel is the indicator that the JavaScript is disabled. It will continue to be disabled until the devtools is closed.
Chrome.Name: Disable JavaScript

Opera.Notes:
1. Open Console using `Cmd+Shift+J `(on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+J` (on Windows/Linux).
2. Next to the "Clear console" icon in the toolbar, click the "top" menu, and select the iframe to target.
Opera.Name: Target iframe

Edge.Notes:
1. Open Console using `Cmd+Shift+J `(on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+J` (on Windows/Linux).
2. Next to the "Clear console" icon in the toolbar, click the "top" menu, and select the iframe to target.
Edge.Name: Target iframe

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open Console using `Cmd+Shift+J `(on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+J` (on Windows/Linux).
2. Next to the "Clear console" icon in the toolbar, click the "top" menu, and select the iframe to target.
Chrome.Name: Target iframe

Safari.Name: Get last return value in console
Safari.Notes: 1. `$_` returns the value of the most recently evaluated expression. Additionally, Safari also lets you access multiple values in chronological order, using `$1, $2, $3`, ...

Opera.Notes: 1. `$_` returns the value of the most recently evaluated expression.
Opera.Name: Get last return value in console

Firefox.Notes: 1. `$_` returns the value of the most recently evaluated expression.
Firefox.Name: Get last return value in console

Edge.Notes: 1. `$_` returns the value of the most recently evaluated expression.
Edge.Name: Get last return value in console

Chrome.Notes: 1. `$_` returns the value of the most recently evaluated expression.
Chrome.Name: Get last return value in console

Opera.Notes:
1. Inspect > Open the Accessibility pane on the right (Click the >> icon to show more tabs, if hidden) > Check "Enable full-page accessibility tree" > Reload Devtools.
2. Click on the floating icon in the top right in the Elements panel which says, "Switch to Accessibility tree view".
Opera.Name: View accessibility tree

Firefox.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Accessibility (Click >> icon to open more tabs if hidden).
2. The main section shows the accessibility tree under the Role section.
Firefox.Name: View accessibility tree

Edge.Notes:
1. Inspect > Elements > Open the Accessibility pane on the right (Click the >> icon to show more tabs, if hidden) > Check "Enable full-page accessibility tree" > Reload Devtools.
2. Click on the floating icon in the top right in the Elements panel which says, "Switch to Accessibility tree view".
Edge.Name: View accessibility tree

Chrome.References:
1. Jecelyn Yeen on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/jecfish/status/1512088763198951431)
2. Full Accessibility Tree by [Chrome Developers](https://developer.chrome.com/blog/full-accessibility-tree/)
Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect > Open the Accessibility pane on the right (Click the >> icon to show more tabs, if hidden) > Check "Enable full-page accessibility tree" > Reload Devtools.
2. Click on the floating icon in the top right in the Elements panel which says, "Switch to Accessibility tree view".
Chrome.Name: View accessibility tree

Opera.Notes:
1. Inspect the text element (this will open the devtools panel).
2. In the Styles pane, look for the section where the `color` property is set for the element.
3. Click on the color square next to the `color` property. This will open the color panel.
4. Expand the "Contrast Ratio" section to see more details whether the color value meets the W3C recommendation.
Opera.Name: Find color contrast ratio

Firefox.Notes:
1. Inspect the text element (this will open the devtools panel).
2. In the pane next to the DOM tree, look for the section where the `color` property is set for the element.
3. Click on the color circle next to the `color` property. This will open the color panel.
Firefox.Name: Check the color contrast ratio of a text element

Edge.Notes:
1. Inspect the text element (this will open the devtools panel).
2. In the Styles pane, look for the section where the `color` property is set for the element.
3. Click on the color square next to the `color` property. This will open the color panel.
4. Expand the "Contrast Ratio" section to see more details whether the color value meets the W3C recommendation.
Edge.Name: Find color contrast ratio

Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect the text element (this will open the devtools panel).
2. In the Styles pane, look for the section where the `color` property is set for the element.
3. Click on the color square next to the `color` property. This will open the color panel.
4. Expand the "Contrast Ratio" section to see more details whether the color value meets the W3C recommendation.
Chrome.Name: Find color contrast ratio

Opera.Notes:
1. Inspect an element > Navigate to the styles section (next to the DOM tree).
2. Add new styles by directly entering the values like "bold", "italic" etc., and the devtools will automatically suggest the corresponding `<attribute>: <value>` pair for the given input.
Opera.Name: Autocomplete styles using values

Edge.Notes:
1. Inspect an element > Navigate to the styles section (next to the DOM tree).
2. Add new styles by directly entering the values like "bold", "italic" etc., and the devtools will automatically suggest the corresponding `<attribute>: <value>` pair for the given input.
Edge.Name: Autocomplete styles using values

Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect an element > Navigate to the styles section (next to the DOM tree).
2. Add new styles by directly entering the values like "bold", "italic" etc., and the devtools will automatically suggest the corresponding `<attribute>: <value>` pair for the given input.
Chrome.Name: Autocomplete styles using values

Opera.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I `(on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux) > Click the triple dot icon in top right > More tools > Rendering.
2. (Or) Run the command menu using `Cmd+Shift+P` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+P` (on Windows/Linux) > Search for "Show Rendering" > Press `Enter` to open the Rendering drawer.
3. Scroll down to the section called "Emulate vision deficiencies" and select the type of deficiency to test your website.
Opera.Name: Simulate vision deficiencies

Firefox.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Accessibility (Click >> icon for more tabs if hidden).
2. Click the Simulate dropdown to test the website against different vision deficiencies.
Firefox.Name: Simulate vision deficiencies

Edge.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I `(on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux) > Click the triple dot icon in top right > More tools > Rendering.
2. (Or) Run the command menu using `Cmd+Shift+P` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+P` (on Windows/Linux) > Search for "Show Rendering" > Press `Enter` to open the Rendering drawer.
3. Scroll down to the section called "Emulate vision deficiencies" and select the type of deficiency to test your website.
Edge.Name: Simulate vision deficiencies
Edge.References:
1. DevTools Tips by [Patrick Brosset](https://devtoolstips.org/tips/en/simulate-color-vision-deficiencies/)
2. Tips & Tricks #3 of the [Newsletter](https://www.getrevue.co/profile/CanIDevTools/issues/tips-tricks-3-1160422)

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I `(on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux) > Click the triple dot icon in top right > More tools > Rendering.
2. (Or) Run the command menu using `Cmd+Shift+P` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+P` (on Windows/Linux) > Search for "Show Rendering" > Press `Enter` to open the Rendering drawer.
3. Scroll down to the section called "Emulate vision deficiencies" and select the type of deficiency to test your website.
Chrome.Name: Simulate vision deficiencies

Safari.Name: Capture full page screenshot
Safari.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Locate the `html` node in the DOM tree.
2. Right click on the node and select "Capture Screenshot"

Opera.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Launch the command menu
2. Search for "Capture full size screenshot" and press Enter
Opera.Name: Capture full page screenshot

Firefox.Notes:
1. Right click on the empty portion of the page > Click on "Take Screenshot"
2. Select the "Choose full page" option in the top right of the page
Firefox.Name: Capture full page screenshot

Edge.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Launch the command menu
2. Search for "Capture full size screenshot" and press Enter
Edge.Name: Capture full page screenshot

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open devtools > Launch the command menu
2. Search for "Capture full size screenshot" and press Enter
Chrome.Name: Capture full page screenshot

Firefox.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux) > Accessibility.
2. Select the checkbox "Show Tabbing Order" to highlight the tab order on the web page.
Firefox.Name: Show tab order

Safari.Name: Locate styles in source
Safari.Notes:
1. Inspect element > Find the corresponding declaration in the styles section. 
2. Click the `<filename>:<lineno>` link adjacent to the declaration to locate the style in the source file.

Opera.Notes:
1. Inspect element > Find the corresponding declaration in the "Styles" pane. 
2. Click the `<filename>:<lineno>` link adjacent to the declaration to locate the style in the source file.
Opera.Name: Locate styles in source

Firefox.Notes:
1. Inspect element > Find the corresponding declaration in the styles section. 
2. Click the `<filename>:<lineno>` link adjacent to the declaration to locate the style in the source file.
Firefox.Name: Locate styles in source

Edge.Notes:
1. Inspect element > Find the corresponding declaration in the "Styles" pane. 
2. Click the `<filename>:<lineno>` link adjacent to the declaration to locate the style in the source file.
Edge.Name: Locate styles in source

Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect element > Find the corresponding declaration in the "Styles" pane. 
2. Click the `<filename>:<lineno>` link adjacent to the declaration to locate the style in the source file.
Chrome.Name: Locate styles in source

Safari.Name: Emulate devices
Safari.Notes: 1. From the menu bar: Develop > Enter Responsive Design Mode (or press `Ctrl+Cmd+R`).

Opera.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I` (on MacOS) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux).
2. Press `Cmd+Shift+M` (on MacOS) or `Ctrl+Shift+M` (on Windows/Linux) or click the devices icon in the top right to "Toggle device toolbar".
Opera.Name: Emulate devices

Firefox.Notes:
There are three ways to toggle Responsive Design Mode:
1. From the Firefox menu: Select **Responsive Design Mode** from the **Web Developer** submenu in the Firefox Menu (or **Tools** menu if you display the menu bar or are on macOS).
2. From the Developer Tools toolbox: Press the **Responsive Design Mode** button in the Toolbox’s toolbar.
3. From the keyboard: Press **Ctrl**+**Shift**+**M** (or **Cmd**+**Opt**+**M** on macOS).
Firefox.Name: Emulate devices

Edge.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I` (on MacOS) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux).
2. Press `Cmd+Shift+M` (on MacOS) or `Ctrl+Shift+M` (on Windows/Linux) or click the devices icon in the top right to "Toggle device toolbar".
Edge.Name: Emulate devices

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I` (on MacOS) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux).
2. Press `Cmd+Shift+M` (on MacOS) or `Ctrl+Shift+M` (on Windows/Linux) or click the devices icon in the top right to "Toggle device toolbar".
Chrome.Name: Emulate devices

Opera.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux) > Sources.
2. Run Command menu using `Cmd+Shift+P` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+P` (on Windows/Linux) > Type filename to filter on the matching files > Press `Enter`.
Opera.Name: Search files in sources

Edge.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux) > Sources.
2. Run Command menu using `Cmd+Shift+P` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+P` (on Windows/Linux) > Type filename to filter on the matching files > Press `Enter`.
Edge.Name: Search files in sources

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux) > Sources.
2. Run Command menu using `Cmd+Shift+P` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+P` (on Windows/Linux) > Type filename to filter on the matching files > Press `Enter`.
Chrome.Name: Search files in sources

Firefox.Notes:
1. [Bugzilla](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/describecomponents.cgi?product=DevTools) - For bugs in Firefox DevTools, the developer tools within the Firefox web browser. This includes issues about the user interface of the toolbox, special pages such as about:debugging and about:devtools, and developer-related APIs.
2. [Discourse](https://discourse.mozilla.org/c/devtools/213) forums 
3. [@FirefoxDevTools](https://twitter.com/FirefoxDevTools) on Twitter
4. [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLgjjGlfBflIRRWuCXnSTU1-35EcDc5Jwf)
Firefox.Name: Report Issues

Chrome.Notes:
Use the following options to discuss the new features and changes in the docs, or anything else related to DevTools.
1. Submit a suggestion or feedback via [crbug.com](https://crbug.com/).
2. Report a DevTools issue using the "More options" > Help > Report a DevTools issues in DevTools.
3. Tweet at [@ChromeDevTools](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=@ChromeDevTools).
4. Leave comments on "What's new in DevTools" [YouTube videos](https://goo.gle/devtools-youtube).
Chrome.Name: Report Issues

Opera.Notes:
1. Open console using `Cmd+Opt+J` or `Ctrl+Shift+J` > Click on the gear icon in top right to open "Console settings".
2. Check "Preserve log" to preserve log statements between page reloads.
Opera.Name: Preserve console logs

Edge.Notes:
1. Open console using `Cmd+Opt+J` or `Ctrl+Shift+J` > Click on the gear icon in top right to open "Console settings".
2. Check "Preserve log" to preserve log statements between page reloads.
Edge.Name: Preserve console logs

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open console using `Cmd+Opt+J` or `Ctrl+Shift+J` > Click on the gear icon in top right to open "Console settings".
2. Check "Preserve log" to preserve log statements between page reloads.
Chrome.Name: Preserve console logs

Opera.Notes:
1. Open settings > Experiments > Filter on "color".
2. Check "Enable color picking outside the browser window" checkbox.
Opera.Name: Use color picker outside window

Edge.Notes:
1. Open settings > Experiments > Filter on "color".
2. Check "Enable color picking outside the browser window" checkbox.
Edge.Name: Use color picker outside window

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open settings > Experiments > Filter on "color".
2. Check "Enable color picking outside the browser window" checkbox.
Chrome.Name: Use color picker outside window

Safari.Name: View ARIA attrs
Safari.Notes:
1. Inspect the element > Click the **Node** pane next to the DOM node.
2. Scroll down to the **Accessibility** section, expand to see all the ARA attributes for the selected node.

Opera.Notes:
1. Inspect the element in the DOM tree.
2. Click on the Accessibility tab (It maybe hidden behind the "More Tabs" button). Scroll down to the section which says, "ARIA Attributes".
Opera.Name: View ARIA attrs

Firefox.Notes:
1. Right click on the element on the page and select "Inspect Accessibility Properties".
2. This will open the Accessibility tab. The ARIA attributes are available under the "Properties" panel on the right.
Firefox.Name: View ARIA attrs

Edge.Notes:
1. Inspect the element in the DOM tree.
2. Click on the Accessibility tab (It maybe hidden behind the "More Tabs" button). Scroll down to the section which says, "ARIA Attributes".
Edge.Name: View ARIA attrs

Chrome.Notes:
1. Inspect the element in the DOM tree.
2. Click on the Accessibility tab (It maybe hidden behind the "More Tabs" button). Scroll down to the section which says, "ARIA Attributes".
Chrome.Name: View ARIA attrs

Safari.Name: Open Console with keyboard
Safari.Notes: 1. Press `Command+Option+C` (Mac) to jump straight into the Console panel.

Opera.Notes: 1. Press `Command+Option+J` (Mac) or `Control+Shift+J` (Windows, Linux, Chrome OS) to jump straight into the Console panel.
Opera.Name: Open Console with keyboard

Firefox.Notes: 1. Press `Command+Shift+K` (Mac) or `Control+Shift+K` (Windows, Linux, Chrome OS) to jump straight into the Console panel.
Firefox.Name: Open Console with keyboard

Edge.Notes: 1. Press `Command+Option+J` (Mac) or `Control+Shift+J` (Windows, Linux, Chrome OS) to jump straight into the Console panel.
Edge.Name: Open Console with keyboard

Chrome.Notes: 1. Press `Command+Option+J` (Mac) or `Control+Shift+J` (Windows, Linux, Chrome OS) to jump straight into the Console panel.
Chrome.Name: Open Console with keyboard

Safari.Name: Audit full page
Safari.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows) > Click the "Audit" tab.
2. Under the Audit section, click the "Start" button in the left side panel to trigger the full page audit for DOM, Accessibility etc.

Opera.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux) > Click the "Lighthouse" tab.
2. Configure the categories, devices, and plugins before hitting the "Generate report" button.
Opera.Name: Audit full page

Edge.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux) > Click the "Lighthouse" tab.
2. Configure the categories, devices, and plugins before hitting the "Generate report" button.
Edge.Name: Audit full page

Chrome.Notes:
1. Open devtools using `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux) > Click the "Lighthouse" tab.
2. Configure the categories, devices, and plugins before hitting the "Generate report" button.
Chrome.Name: Audit full page

Opera.Notes:
1. Right click > Inspect element or Press `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux).
2. Select the node and drag-n-drop to a different part of the DOM tree.
Opera.Name: Drag Drop element

Firefox.Notes:
1. Right click > Inspect element or Press `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux).
2. Select the node and drag-n-drop to a different part of the DOM tree.
Firefox.Name: Drag Drop element

Edge.Notes:
1. Right click > Inspect element or Press `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux).
2. Select the node and drag-n-drop to a different part of the DOM tree.
Edge.Name: Drag Drop element

Chrome.Notes:
1. Right click > Inspect element or Press `Cmd+Opt+I` (on Mac) or `Ctrl+Shift+I` (on Windows/Linux).
2. Select the node and drag-n-drop to a different part of the DOM tree.
Chrome.Name: Drag Drop element
